The average monthly churn rate of wireless carriers refers to the average percentage of subscribers that cease to use the company’s services per month. AT&T’s churn rate in the second quarter of 2014 stood at 1.47 percent, the second lowest of all the wireless carriers in the U.S. The Texas-based company’s churn rate has remained relatively stable in recent years, although it has risen slightly since it was at its lowest of 1.31 percent in 2010.

Churn is closely related to the concept of average customer life time. For example, an annual churn rate of 25% implies an average customer life of 4 years.
